channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: U.N. Inspectors Call for Security Zone Around Nuclear Plant
item.description: The nuclear watchdog agency, which will later brief the U.N. Security Council, said that shelling around the Zaporizhzhia complex should be “stopped immediately.”
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Remnants of Russian military equipment in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: Police Discount Sighting of 2nd Stabbing Suspect in Canada
item.description: Officers converged on a house on the Indigenous reserve where two brothers were accused of launching an attack that killed 10 people, but later said he was still at large.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Amber Bracken for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ivor Wayne Burns, right, and Cruze Paul at home in James Smith Cree Nation, Saskatchewan, on Tuesday. Mr. Burns’s sister was among the victims of the mass stabbing.

item.title: In India’s Tech Capital, Floods Leave Workers Riding Tractors to Work
item.description: Bengaluru, India’s Silicon Valley, joined the roster of places in South Asia inundated by torrential rains during this monsoon season.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir and Emily Schmall
item.media:description: People pulling a car through a water-logged road following torrential rains in Bengaluru, on Monday.

item.title: Israel Recalls Envoy to Morocco After Harassment Claims
item.description: Israel is investigating accusations against David Govrin over his conduct in Rabat, the Moroccan capital. The two countries sealed formal ties in 2020 as part of a wider regional realignment.
item.dc:creator: Aida Alami and Patrick Kingsley

item.title: Liz Truss Takes Over as Prime Minister, Promising Britons They Can ‘Ride Out the Storm’
item.description: Liz Truss takes over as prime minister at a time of deepening economic crisis. Her first cabinet appointments reward loyalists who supported her bid for office.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Britain’s new prime minister, Liz Truss, with her husband, Hugh O’Leary, after giving her first speech, at Downing Street on Tuesday.

item.title: In Energy Crunch, Germany Turns Down Heat but Won’t Limit Autobahn Speeds
item.description: Putting general restrictions on the country’s storied highways is a simple step to save energy, carbon emissions and lives. But even with the Greens in power, the country is unlikely to take it.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Many of Germany’s autobahns have no speed limits. The German Environment Ministry found that adding restrictions could save 2.1 billion liters of fuel each year.

item.title: In Moscow, the Fighting Is a World Away
item.description: A detachment from the battle in Ukraine is exactly what President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia is counting on as he carries out a domestic strategy of shielding his people from hardships.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Nanna Heitmann
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times

item.title: A ‘Period Dignity Officer’ Seemed Like a Good Idea. Until a Man Was Named.
item.description: The job in the Scottish region of Tayside was eliminated after a groundswell of anger that a man would be overseeing, or ‘mansplaining,’ menstruation policy.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: The Scottish Parliament. Scotland was the first country to adopt a law requiring universal free access to period products.

item.title: Battling Violence and Censors, Women in China Become ‘Invisible and Absent’
item.description: The Chinese Communist Party has long promoted gender equality as a core tenet, but as cases of gender abuse make headlines, Beijing has tried to squelch dissent and control the narrative.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Zixu Wang
item.media:description: Zhou Xiaoxuan in August lost her appeal against a famous TV anchor she had accused of sexual assault.

item.title: How Will Ukraine Rebuild (and Who Should Pay)?
item.description: A report to Western donors before a major reconstruction conference next month urges quick decisions, phased investment and strict foreign oversight of any aid.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A bombed bridge across the Irpin River near Kyiv in April. A report from the German Marshall Fund envisages a total of some $100 billion to rebuild Ukraine’s infrastructure.

item.title: Canada Stabbing Suspect Remains at Large After Manhunt in Saskatchewan
item.description: The police received reports that Myles Sanderson was spotted at the Indigenous reserve where the stabbings took place, but by day’s end he was not in custody, and an emergency alert was still in place for Saskatchewan.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen, Vjosa Isai and Yonette Joseph
item.media:credit: Amber Bracken for The New York Times
item.media:description: A police vehicle at James Smith Cree Nation after a report that Myles Sanderson may have been spotted there.

item.title: U.N. Team Calls for No-Fire Zone at Ukraine Nuclear Plant
item.description: In a highly anticipated report, nuclear experts who crossed a battlefield to inspect Europe’s largest nuclear plant called for Russia and Ukraine to halt all military activity around the complex.
item.dc:creator: Eric Nagourney and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: The director general of the U.N. nuclear watchdog, Rafael Mariano Grossi, addressing the Security Council on Tuesday.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: South Korea Skirts a Typhoon
item.description: Plus Russia and North Korea grow closer, and Apple prepares to introduce its newest iPhone.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Flooded homes in Seondu village in Gyeongju city, South Korea, on Tuesday.

item.title: Who Will Liz Truss Appoint to Her Cabinet?
item.description: The announcements, expected later on Tuesday, are likely to reward loyalists and overlook defeated rivals.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Liz Truss is expected to choose Kwasi Kwarteng for chancellor of the Exchequer. Rishi Sunak, who quit the post in July, lost the battle for prime minister to Ms. Truss.

item.title: It’s A Challenging Time To Be @Liztruss on Twitter
item.description: The woman who has owned the account since 2009 is having fun replying to well wishers and world leaders who tag her, thinking she is Britain’s new prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai

item.title: South Korea Is Spared as Typhoon Hinnamnor Makes Swift Exit
item.description: The storm brought heavy rain and blackouts near the southern coast, but its fast pace kept the country from experiencing the severe damage caused by floods in August.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Firefighters surveying the water level at a flooded underground parking lot in Pohang where seven people went missing after Typhoon Hinnamnor hit.

item.title: Bomb Attack in Burkina Faso Kills Dozens of Civilians
item.description: At least 35 people were killed and dozens of others wounded when a roadside blast struck a convoy. The country has been devastated by growing violence driven by extremist groups.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier

item.title: A Good Issue for Democrats
item.description: Despite the large partisan gaps on many aspects of Covid, Americans give Democrats higher marks for pandemic management than Republicans.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt

item.title: Larry the Cat Will Stay at No. 10 Downing Street
item.description: The chief mouser to the Cabinet Office will remain in 10 Downing Street even after Britain welcomes Liz Truss as prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Euan Ward
item.media:description: Larry the Cat outside of Downing Street, after Boris Johnson departed on Tuesday.

item.title: How One Couple Uprooted Their Life to Open an Inn in the Catskills
item.description: In early 2020, Maureen McNamara and her wife, Jennifer Stark, traded in their popular restaurant in Michigan for an inn nestled in the Catskill Mountains of New York. The inn opened just days before the pandemic was declared.
item.dc:creator: Alix Strauss
item.media:credit: Jasmine Clarke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jennifer Stark, left, and Maureen McNamara took a leap of faith and opened the Phoenicia Lodge in the Catskill Mountains of New York in early 2020.

item.title: Scenes From the Aftermath of Typhoon Hinnamnor
item.description: The storm swept past South Korea’s southeastern corner, causing at least three deaths, sparking a fire at a steel plant and leaving tens of thousands without power.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim and Chang W. Lee
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Flooding in Gyeongju, South Korea, on Tuesday in the wake of Typhoon Hinnamnor.

item.title: It Was War. Then, a Rancher’s Truce With Some Pesky Beavers Paid Off.
item.description: The ‘highly skilled environmental engineers’ can help to store precious water and rejuvenate land ravaged by climate change. Just don’t dynamite their homes.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn and Niki Chan Wylie

item.title: Biden Puts Defense of Democracy at Center of Agenda, at Home and Abroad
item.description: President Biden’s foreign policy priority overlaps with a main domestic drive — both made more urgent by the persistent power of China, Russia and Donald J. Trump.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: President Biden warned about the threat to democracy in the United States last week during a speech in Philadelphia.

item.title: Why Liz Truss is Meeting Queen Elizabeth at Balmoral
item.description: The meeting, usually performed at Buckingham Palace, was moved as the 96-year-old monarch faces health challenges.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Balmoral Castle was built for Queen Victoria in the 1850s, and has remained a summer retreat for royals ever since.

item.title: In Farewell Speech, Boris Johnson Pledges to Support Liz Truss
item.description: The outgoing prime minister defended his three-year tenure but appealed to his party to unite around his successor.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Boris Johnson speaking outside Downing Street in London on Tuesday.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: A special master will review Mar-a-Lago files.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Hannah Beier for The New York Times
item.media:description: A federal judge said that a special master could evaluate the documents seized from former President Donald J. Trump’s estate.

item.title: Saskatchewan Stabbings Suspect Found Dead, Canada’s Police Say
item.description: The body of a man being sought by the authorities was found with wounds that were not believed to be self-inflicted. The killing of 10 people stunned the country.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen, Amber Bracken and Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: Amber Bracken for The New York Times
item.media:description: Two officers investigating a home on Monday in Weldon, Saskatchewan, where an older man who was believed to be a victim of the mass killing lived.

item.title: Ukraine Nuclear Plant Disconnected From Grid After Shelling
item.description: A fire caused by shelling forced the staff of Europe’s largest nuclear plant to disconnect from the nation’s power grid, showing that risks remained at the plant despite the presence of U.N. experts.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Ivan Nechepurenko and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: A motorcade transporting the International Atomic Energy Agency expert mission arriving at the Zaporizhzhia power plant last week.

item.title: In Somalia, ‘Famine Is at the Door,’ U.N. Warns
item.description: A U.N. official stopped short of officially declaring a famine in the country. But some aid workers said that the threshold had already been reached.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Malin Fezehai for The New York Times
item.media:description: A settlement for displaced people in Doolow, in Somalia’s southern Gedo region, in May. A severe drought has left half the country’s population in need of food assistance.

item.title: Liz Truss to Replace Boris Johnson at a Time of Crisis for Britain
item.description: Ms. Truss, who prevailed over Rishi Sunak, will be greeted by an array of vexing problems, including double-digit inflation, a looming recession, labor unrest and soaring household energy bills.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Liz Truss at the Conservative Party headquarters in London on Monday after it was announced that she had prevailed in the contest to be Britain's next prime minister.

item.title: The police have been criticized for their handling of crimes against Indigenous people.
item.description: After the Sunday stabbings, police treatment of Indigenous communities is under scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Amber Bracken for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of Colten Boushie’s family outside the courthouse during the trial of Gerald Stanley in Battleford, Saskatchewan, in 2018.

item.title: Russia Sentences Journalist Ivan Safronov to 22 Years in Prison On Treason Charges
item.description: The prosecution of Ivan Safronov, a former defense reporter, sent chills through the Russian journalism community.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Alina Lobzina
item.media:description: Ivan Safronov denied accusations that he had disclosed state secrets and refused to enter a plea deal.

item.title: Breaking Taboo, Germany Extends Life of 2 Nuclear Reactors
item.description: The step is intended to cushion a growing energy crisis in Europe but could upend the country’s plans to become the first industrial power to shutter its program.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon and Melissa Eddy
item.media:description: The Isar 2 nuclear power plant in Essenbach, Germany.

item.title: 50 Years After Attack at Munich Olympics, a Formal German Apology
item.description: Palestinian militants killed 11 Israeli athletes at the Olympic Games in 1972. Decades later Germany asked the victims’ families for forgiveness for not keeping the delegation safe.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Pictures of the victims of the massacre at the 1972 Olympics in Munich at a ceremony on Monday to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the attack, which left 11 Israeli athletes and a German policeman dead.

item.title: Horror grips a bucolic farming region after the killing spree.
item.description: Police searches and the roar of helicopters disrupt the routine in a rural stretch of Saskatchewan.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky and Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Heywood Yu/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: An investigator in protective equipment worked at a crime scene in Weldon, Saskatchewan, on Sunday.

item.title: Of Barbecues and Men: A Summer Storm Brews Over Virility in France
item.description: A Green politician told men to get over meat and masculinity for the sake of the planet, setting off a sizzling argument.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: Sandrine Rousseau, a member of parliament from the Greens, has thrust barbecue to the center of French debate.

item.title: Israel Says Shireen Abu Akleh Most Likely Shot by Israeli Soldier
item.description: The Israeli Army has concluded that Shireen Abu Akleh, a Palestinian-American broadcaster, was probably killed by one of its own soldiers — but stopped short of accepting definitive blame.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Samar Hazboun for The New York Times
item.media:description: The site where Shireen Abu Akleh, a Palestinian-American journalist, was shot and killed in the West Bank town of Jenin.

item.title: Strong Earthquake Shakes China’s Sichuan Province, Killing 65
item.description: Government agencies said at least 65 people had died, but communications in the landslide-prone area were disrupted and the full extent of the damage was unclear.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: A road in China’s Sichuan Province after an earthquake on Monday, in a photo from the Chinese news agency Xinhua.

item.title: Suicide Attack Hits Russian Embassy in Afghanistan, Killing 2 Employees
item.description: The bombing in Kabul, which also left 4 Afghan civilians dead, was the first strike on a diplomatic mission since the Taliban regained control.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: A Taliban fighter outside the Russian Embassy in Kabul, Afghanistan, after the attack on Monday. The blast was the latest in a steady drumbeat of suicide bombings in the country in recent months.

item.title: Liz Truss Is Expected to Increase Britain’s Support of Ukraine
item.description: As foreign secretary, Ms. Truss back in March said “Putin must lose,” using language that went beyond that of the U.S. and other Western allies.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Liz Truss with Ukraine’s foreign minister, Dmytro Kuleba, in Warsaw in April.

item.title: Museums in the U.S. and Europe Are in Blockbuster Mode
item.description: From Los Angeles to Antwerp, Jason Farago, our critic at large, picks a fall season laden with offerings on Cubism, modern Korean art and paintings of the Spanish Baroque.
item.dc:creator: Jason Farago
item.category: Los Angeles County Museum of Art
Cubism and the Trompe l'Oeil Tradition (Exhibit)

item.title: Rising Energy Prices and High Inflation: The Economic Issues Facing Liz Truss
item.description: Consumer prices in Britain are rising at their fastest pace in decades, as the inflation rate exceeds 10 percent and is expected to keep climbing.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:description: The Bank of England is forecasting a long recession to begin later this year as wages lag and household budgets are squeezed.
